elements.content: Hydrothermal reaction of zinc nitrate, 4-(4-carboxyphenoxy)­phthalate acid (H3cpop), and different N-donor coligands has afforded six novel supramolecular compounds, in which the nature of the neutral coligands plays a crucial structure-directing role. [Zn­(Hcpop)­(H2O)3] n (1) and [Zn­(Hcpop)­(phen)­(H2O)] n (2, phen = 1,10-phenanthroline) form three-dimensional (3D) supramolecular frameworks linked by H-bonds and π–π interactions based on discrete molecules. Similarly, [Zn2(Hcpop)2(4,4′-bpy)3(H2O)2] n ·4nH2O (3) possesses a 3D supramolecular structure, aggregated by interesting one-dimensional (1D) armed-polyrotaxane chains. [Zn6(cpop)4(4,4′-bpy)2(H2O)2] n (4, 4,4′-bpy = 4,4′-bipyridine) exhibits a complicated 3D framework, which can be rationalized as a (3,6,6)-connected trinodal net with a unique (4.62)2(42.69.83.10)­(44.68.83) topology. [Zn3(cpop)2(bpdb)­(H2O)2] n (5, bpdb = 1,4-bis­(4-pyridyl)-2,3-diaza-1,3-butadiene) is a 3D structure containing two-dimensional (2D) metal–carboxylate layers motifs, which are further pillared by cpop3– and bpdb ligands to complete the structure. [Zn6(cpop)4(azpy)2(H2O)4] n (6, azpy = 4,4′-azopyridine) manifests a unique quadruple layer structure constructed from two types of bilayered architectures linked by Zn2+ ions and bridging azpy ligands. Meanwhile, solid-state properties such as thermal stability and the photoluminescence properties at room temperature for these complexes have also been systematically investigated.

[Zn(Hcpop)(H2O)3] n  (1) and [Zn(Hcpop)(phen)(H2O)] n  (2, phen = 1,10-phenanthroline) form three-dimensional (3D) supramolecular frameworks linked by H-bonds and π-π interactions based on discrete molecules. Similarly, [Zn2(Hcpop)2(4,4'-bpy)3(H2O)2] n ⋅4nH2O (3) possesses a 3D supramolecular structure, aggregated by interesting one-dimensional (1D) armed-polyrotaxane chains. [Zn6(cpop)4(4,4'-bpy)2(H2O)2] n  (4, 4,4'-bpy = 4,4'-bipyridine) exhibits a complicated 3D framework, which can be rationalized as a (3,6,6)-connected trinodal net with a unique (4.62)2(42.69.83.10)(44.68.83) topology. [Zn3(cpop)2(bpdb)(H2O)2] n  (5, bpdb = 1,4-bis(4-pyridyl)-2,3-diaza-1,3-butadiene) is a 3D structure containing two-dimensional (2D) metal-carboxylate layers motifs, which are further pillared by cpop3- and bpdb ligands to complete the structure. [Zn6(cpop)4(azpy)2(H2O)4] n  (6, azpy = 4,4'-azopyridine) manifests a unique quadruple layer structure constructed from two types of bilayered architectures linked by Zn2+ ions and bridging azpy ligands. Meanwhile, solid-state properties such as thermal stability and the photoluminescence properties at room temperature for these complexes have also been systematically investigated.

elements.content: Six zinc­(II)-4-(4-carboxyphenoxy)­phthalate complexes with a variety of discrete one-, two-, and three-dimensional architectures have been isolated through varying N-donor auxiliary ligands. The result reveals that assistant N-donor ligands can not only affect the construction of coordination framework but also may further mediate their optical properties.
elements.clean_text: Six zinc(II)-4-(4-carboxyphenoxy)phthalate complexes with a variety of discrete one-, two-, and three-dimensional architectures have been isolated through varying N-donor auxiliary ligands. The result reveals that assistant N-donor ligands can not only affect the construction of coordination framework but also may further mediate their optical properties.

elements.content: The past decades have seen significant growth of interest in coordination polymers (CPs), because these solid-state materials have not only topologically interesting architectures, but also potential applications in functional materials. It is well-known that the construction of metal–organic frameworks mainly depends on the nature of metal ions and sites of the organic ligands. However, the preparation of CPs with predictable structures and valuable properties is still a great challenge because many subtle factors, such as temperature, solvent, pH value, and the ratio between metal salts and ligands, have nonignorable influence on the crystallization process.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The past decades have seen significant growth of interest in coordination polymers (CPs), because these solid-state materials have not only topologically interesting architectures, but also potential applications in functional materials. It is well-known that the construction of metal-organic frameworks mainly depends on the nature of metal ions and sites of the organic ligands. However, the preparation of CPs with predictable structures and valuable properties is still a great challenge because many subtle factors, such as temperature, solvent, pH value, and the ratio between metal salts and ligands, have nonignorable influence on the crystallization process.

elements.content: In the past few years, the design of appropriate organic ligands favoring structure-specific self-assembly has been an important way to construct coordination polymers. Among the reported studies, polycarboxylic acids, as a crucial family of multidentate O-donor ligands, are the most popular choice of connecting ligands in the formation of metal–organic polymers with diverse multidimensional architectures. Notably, most of the reports focus on the rigid and flexible carboxylate ligands. The former, such as 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate (BDC), 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (BTC), and 1,3,5-tris­(4-carboxyphenyl)­benzene (BTB), have been extensively used for fabricating porous materials. Meanwhile, the latter, like aliphatic dicarboxylate ligands, prove to be good candidates for preparing interpenetrating structures and metal clusters with high-nuclearity. Recently, a new type of ligand with flexibility falling between, called a semirigid V-shaped multicarboxylate ligand, has attracted increasing attention from chemists. This type of ligand features a nonmetallic atom (C, O, S, and N atoms) center connecting two rigid benzene-polycarboxylic moieties. According to previous literature, CPs with a wide range of interesting interpenetrating networks as well as potential applications in the gas sorption, separation, and catalysts are accessible in metal V-shaped multicarboxylate ligand system. On the standpoint of this, we were thus intrigued to focus on a semirigid V-shaped multicarboxylate ligand, 4-(4-carboxyphenoxy)­phthalic acid (H3cpop). This ligand exhibits a modicum of conformational flexibility around the central nonmetallic atoms with various coordination modes from complete or partial deprotonated forms, which has proven useful in accessing great structural diversity.

Meanwhile, the latter, like aliphatic dicarboxylate ligands, prove to be good candidates for preparing interpenetrating structures and metal clusters with high-nuclearity. Recently, a new type of ligand with flexibility falling between, called a semirigid V-shaped multicarboxylate ligand, has attracted increasing attention from chemists. This type of ligand features a nonmetallic atom (C, O, S, and N atoms) center connecting two rigid benzene-polycarboxylic moieties. According to previous literature, CPs with a wide range of interesting interpenetrating networks as well as potential applications in the gas sorption, separation, and catalysts are accessible in metal V-shaped multicarboxylate ligand system. elements.content: On the other hand, because of the strong coordination affinity and capability of satisfying and mediating geometric need of metal centers, it is effective to introduce auxiliary connectors in preparing metal carboxylate coordination polymers with higher-dimensional structures and novel topologies. From another point of view, among various types of complexes, those containing metal ions with a d10 configuration, such as Zn­(II), Cd­(II), show intriguing fluorescent behavior relevant to potential applications in light-emitting diodes (LEDs). Herein, reactions of zinc­(II) salt and semirigid V-shaped 4-(4-carboxyphenoxy)­phthalic acid together with different N-donor ligands were carried out to investigate the influence of organic ligands on the coordination architectures and properties. In this Article, six novel d10 metal coordination polymers with diverse molecular structures including two discrete molecules [Zn­(Hcpop)­(H2O)3] n (1) and [Zn­(Hcpop)­(phen)­(H2O)] n (2), one 1D complex [Zn2(Hcpop)2(4,4′-bpy)3(H2O)2] n ·4nH2O (3), one 2D layered structure [Zn6(cpop)4(azpy)2(H2O)4] n (6), and two 3D frameworks [Zn6(cpop)4(4,4′-bpy)2(H2O)2] n (4) and [Zn3(cpop)2(bpdb)­(H2O)2] n (5) (phen = 1,10-phenanthroline, 4,4′-bpy = 4,4′-bipyridine, azpy = 4,4′-azopyridine, bpdb = 1,4-bis­(4-pyridyl)-2,3-diaza-1,3-butadiene) are reported. Their luminescent properties have also been probed.

elements.content: All reactants were reagent grade and used as purchased without further purification. Elemental analyses for C, H, N were carried out on a German Elementary Vario EL III instrument. The FT-IR spectra were performed on a Nicolet Magna 750 FT-IR spectrometer using KBr pellets in the range of 4000–400 cm–1. Thermogravimetric analyses were recorded on a NETZSCH STA 449C unit at a heating rate of 10 °C min–1 under nitrogen atmosphere. The power X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were collected by a Rigaku DMAX2500 X-ray diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.154 nm). Fluorescent analysis of the complexes was performed on Fluorolog-3.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

All reactants were reagent grade and used as purchased without further purification. Elemental analyses for C, H, N were carried out on a German Elementary Vario EL III instrument. The FT-IR spectra were performed on a Nicolet Magna 750 FT-IR spectrometer using KBr pellets in the range of 4000-400 cm-1. Thermogravimetric analyses were recorded on a NETZSCH STA 449C unit at a heating rate of 10 °C min-1 under nitrogen atmosphere. The power X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were collected by a Rigaku DMAX2500 X-ray diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.154 nm). Fluorescent analysis of the complexes was performed on Fluorolog-3.

elements.content: A mixture of Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (0.4 mmol, 118 mg), H3cpop (0.1 mmol, 32 mg), and H2O (10 mL) was placed in a Teflon-lined steel autoclave (23 mL). The pH of this mixture solution was about 6.0. The autoclave was sealed, heated to 120 °C, and held at the temperature for 96 h. The autoclave was allowed to cool to 30 °C for 24 h. Colorless block-shaped crystals of compound 1 were collected in 68% yield based on H3cpop. Anal. Calcd for C15O10H14Zn (M r = 419.65): C, 42.93; H, 3.36. Found: C, 43.12; H, 3.28. Selected IR data (KBr pellet, cm–1): 3302 (s), 2502 (m), 1897 (w), 1676 (s), 1587 (vs), 1392 (vs), 1261 (vs), 1242 (vs), 1169 (s), 1148 (m), 988 (w), 834 (m), 777 (s), 675 (m), 630 (m), 575 (m).

elements.content: All structure data of complexes 1–6 were collected on a Rigaku Mercury CCD diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. All of the structures were resolved by the direct method and refined by full-matrix least-squares fitting on F 2 by SHELX-97. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. The hydrogen atoms of the water molecules and carboxylic groups were found in the electron density map and refined by riding. The other hydrogen atoms were located at geometrically calculated positions and refined by riding. A carboxylic group (C2, C2′; O4, O4′) in 2 is disordered and refined using C atoms and O atoms split over two equivalent sites with a total occupancy of 1. Crystallographic data and structure refinement parameters for complexes 1–6 are summarized in Table . Selected bond lengths and bond angles are listed in the (Table S1). More details on the crystallographic studies as well as atomic displacement parameters are given in the as CIF files.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

All structure data of complexes 1-6 were collected on a Rigaku Mercury CCD diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. All of the structures were resolved by the direct method and refined by full-matrix least-squares fitting on F 2 by SHELX-97. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. The hydrogen atoms of the water molecules and carboxylic groups were found in the electron density map and refined by riding. The other hydrogen atoms were located at geometrically calculated positions and refined by riding. A carboxylic group (C2, C2'; O4, O4') in 2 is disordered and refined using C atoms and O atoms split over two equivalent sites with a total occupancy of 1. Crystallographic data and structure refinement parameters for complexes 1-6 are summarized in Table . Selected bond lengths and bond angles are listed in the  (Table S1). More details on the crystallographic studies as well as atomic displacement parameters are given in the  as CIF files.

elements.clean_text: 1  Coordination Modes of H3cpop Ligands in Complexes 1-6

elements.content: Crystal structure data of 1 reveal a zero-dimensional (0D) molecule based on a dinuclear unit consisting of two Zn2+ ions, two partly deprotonated Hcpop2– ligands, and six aqua ligands (Figure ). The asymmetry unit of 1 contains only one-half of the dinuclear unit, and the two Zn2+ ions here are associated with a center inversion operation. Each Zn2+ ion lies in an octahedral O6 environment. Three oxygen atoms come from the carboxyl groups of two Hcpop2– ligands, which adopt the μ-κO:κO′,O″ mode (Scheme a) to bridge the two Zn2+ ions. Also, the remaining three oxygen atoms are from three terminally coordinated water molecules. There are abundant hydrogen bonds in 1 (Table ). The distance between the dinuclear Zn2+ ions is 4.418 Å, and the dinuclear units are conjoined into a 2D net (Figure a,b) through two types of hydrogen bonds. One is between uncoordinated carboxyl groups and carboxyl groups belonging to another Hcpop2– ligand (O1···O6iii = 2.581(2) Å). The other is among uncoordinated carboxyl groups and water molecules (O10···O2iv = 2.861(2) Å). The neighboring 2D layers are further stacked via the strong O–H···O interactions between water molecules and carboxyl groups (O8···O6i = 2.771(2) Å, O9···O2ii = 2.743(2) Å, O10···O5v = 2.838(2) Å, O9···O4vi = 2.849(2) Å), giving a 3D supramolecular framework (Figure c).

elements.content: Complex 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c. The discrete Zn­(II) complex within 2 is a neutral dinuclear complex with two Zn2+ ions, two μ-bridging partly deprotonated Hcpop2– ligands, two chelating phen ligands, and two terminal water molecules (Figure a). The asymmetry unit contains only one-half of the dinuclear unit; that is, the two Zn2+ ions are equivalent. The Zn2+ ion possesses a disordered square pyramidal coordination geometry with two nitrogen atoms of a phen ligand, two oxygen atoms from two different Hcpop2– ligands, and one aqua ligand. The H3cpop ligands are partly deprotonated, the phthalic groups thus serve as bridges to connect dinuclear Zn2+ ions via μ-κO:κO′ mode (Scheme b), and the other protonated carboxylic groups act as hydrogen-bonding donors. The distance between the dinuclear Zn2+ ions is 5.134(1) Å.
elements.clean_text:
Structural Description of [Zn(Hcpop)(phen)(H2O)] n  (2)

Complex 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c. The discrete Zn(II) complex within 2 is a neutral dinuclear complex with two Zn2+ ions, two μ-bridging partly deprotonated Hcpop2- ligands, two chelating phen ligands, and two terminal water molecules (Figure a). The asymmetry unit contains only one-half of the dinuclear unit; that is, the two Zn2+ ions are equivalent. The Zn2+ ion possesses a disordered square pyramidal coordination geometry with two nitrogen atoms of a phen ligand, two oxygen atoms from two different Hcpop2- ligands, and one aqua ligand. The H3cpop ligands are partly deprotonated, the phthalic groups thus serve as bridges to connect dinuclear Zn2+ ions via μ-κO:κO' mode (Scheme b), and the other protonated carboxylic groups act as hydrogen-bonding donors. The distance between the dinuclear Zn2+ ions is 5.134(1) Å.

elements.content: Some interesting supramolecular contacts are observed in the solid-state structure of 2. Besides strong intermolecular hydrogen bonds with an O5···O2i (i = 1 + x, y, 1 + z) distance of 2.602(4) Å found between the oxygen atoms of protonated carboxylic groups and uncoordinated carboxylic oxygen atoms of another Hcpop2– ligand, obvious π–π stacking interactions provided by the nearly parallel rings C19–C24 and rings N1ii–C21ii–C22ii–C25ii–C26ii–C27ii (ii = 2 – x, 2 – y, 1 – z; centroid distance, Cg–Cg = 3.508 Å) belonging to the adjacent phen ligands link together the dinuclear units into a 1D supramolecular chain (Figure b). Further extension of the 1D chains generates a 3D network with the help of weak π–π interactions between the rings C3–C8 and C9iii–C14iii (iii = x, 5/2 – y, 1/2 + z) with the shortest distances 3.660(1) Å among the atoms from one ring to the others (Cg–Cg = 4.167 Å and dihedral angle 15.60°) as shown in Figure c.

Further extension of the 1D chains generates a 3D network with the help of weak π-π interactions between the rings C3-C8 and C9iii-C14iii (iii = x, 5/2 - y, 1/2 + z) with the shortest distances 3.660(1) Å among the atoms from one ring to the others (Cg-Cg = 4.167 Å and dihedral angle 15.60°) as shown in Figure c.

elements.content: Complex 3 was synthesized by introducing rod-like N-donor (4,4′-bpy) secondary ligand instead of the chelating N-donor (phen) ligand. X-ray crystallographic analysis reveals that the Zn2+ center is five-coordinated by two nitrogen atoms of two 4,4′-bpy ligands, three oxygen atoms from two Hcpop2– ligands, and one aqua ligand (Figure ). Therefore, the Zn2+ center adopts slightly distorted trigonal bipyramidal coordination geometry. Two partly deprotonated Hcpop2– ligands bridge two Zn2+ ions via μ-κO:κO′ mode (Scheme c) to form a ring structure, and each metal bears a terminally coordinated 4,4′-bpy ligand (Figure a). This ring structure looks as a rectangular window of approximate dimensions 7.048 × 8.302 Å, and the distance between the two zinc ions is 10.138 Å. The ring structures are further connected by the μ-4,4′-bpy ligands lying on the inversion center. The μ-4,4′-bpy ligand links two Zn2+ atoms of adjacent window to make the ring structures a one-dimensional chain (Figure b).
elements.clean_text:
Structural Description of [Zn2(Hcpop)2(4,4'-bpy)3(H2O)2] n ⋅4nH2O (3)

Complex 3 was synthesized by introducing rod-like N-donor (4,4'-bpy) secondary ligand instead of the chelating N-donor (phen) ligand. X-ray crystallographic analysis reveals that the Zn2+ center is five-coordinated by two nitrogen atoms of two 4,4'-bpy ligands, three oxygen atoms from two Hcpop2- ligands, and one aqua ligand (Figure ). Therefore, the Zn2+ center adopts slightly distorted trigonal bipyramidal coordination geometry. Two partly deprotonated Hcpop2- ligands bridge two Zn2+ ions via μ-κO:κO' mode (Scheme c) to form a ring structure, and each metal bears a terminally coordinated 4,4'-bpy ligand (Figure a). This ring structure looks as a rectangular window of approximate dimensions 7.048 × 8.302 Å, and the distance between the two zinc ions is 10.138 Å. The ring structures are further connected by the μ-4,4'-bpy ligands lying on the inversion center. The μ-4,4'-bpy ligand links two Zn2+ atoms of adjacent window to make the ring structures a one-dimensional chain (Figure b).

elements.content: Interestingly, as shown in Figure a,b, the 1D chains of 3 are interlocked in pairs and form a fascinating topology-armed-polyrotaxane. These polyrotaxane chains are decorated with 4,4′-bpy ligands alternately at both sides, and the uncoordinated pyridyl rings of the 4,4′-bpy ligands are arranged parallelly with the centroid distance of 14.710 Å. The most striking characteristic of 3 is that a three-dimensional supramolecular framework is built from the polyrotaxane chains and water molecules via supramolecular interactions (Table ). First, each terminally coordinated 4,4′-bpy ligand extends out of one polyrotaxane chain to recognize an aqua ligand of adjacent polymeric chain. The strong O–H···N (O10···N2ii = 2.799(3) Å) intermolecular hydrogen-bonding interactions along approximately the [011] direction make the one-dimensional chains a two-dimensional layer. At the same time, the 2D layer is stabilized by π–π interactions between the terminally coordinated 4,4′-bpy ligands (Cg–Cg = 3.701 Å) as shown in Figure S1 (). Second, there are strong hydrogen-bonding interactions between the uncoordinated carboxylic oxygen atoms and lattice water molecules along the c axis (O5···O9i = 2.605(3) Å, O8···O4i = 2.845(4) Å, O9···O8iii = 2.770(4) Å) (). With the help of these intermolecular weak interactions, the 1D polyrotaxane chains extend to a 3D supramolecular framework (Figure c).

elements.clean_text:
Structural Description of [Zn6(cpop)4(4,4'-bpy)2(H2O)2] n  (4)

In contrast to 3, complex 4 was obtained by adjusting the pH value of the same reaction mixture to 8.0. Complex 4 crystallizes in the rare space group P1, featuring a complicated 3D molecular structure. In addition, calculation by PLATON also supports the P1 space group for 4.

elements.content: The asymmetric unit consists of six independent Zn­(II) ions, four fully deprotonated cpop3– ligands, two 4,4′-bpy ligands, and two coordinated water molecules as shown in Figure a. To best understand the structure of complex 4, the topology analysis is employed. First, we divide the asymmetric unit of 4 into two parts, binuclear [Zn2(CO2)4(pyridine)2] paddle-wheel unit and tetra-nuclear [Zn4(phthalate)2(CO2)4(pyridine)2] unit. The binuclear paddle-wheel unit contains two tetragonal-pyramidal Zn­(II) centers (Zn1 and Zn2) binding to four symmetry equivalent syn–syn bidentate carboxylate groups belonging to four independent cpop3– ligands, respectively, and two pyridine groups from 4,4′-bpy ligands at the axial position. The Zn1···Zn2 separation is 2.8727(2) Å, which is in agreement with the value of the reported binuclear zinc-carboxylate paddle-wheel unit. Each cpop3– ligand adopts μ5-κO:κO′:κO″:κO′′′:κO′′′′ mode (Scheme d) to connect two binuclear units and one tetra-nuclear units, and each 4,4′-bpy ligand serves as a bridge to link two adjacent binuclear units together. Therefore, the cpop3– ligands around the binuclear units can be viewed as 3-connected topological nodes, and the paddle-wheel structure can be abstracted to a 6-connected node (). The tetra-nuclear unit contains two binuclear subunits, which are conjoined by two bridging phthalic groups from two cpop3– ligands, respectively. The first binuclear unit [Zn2(COO)3] is built from Zn3 and Zn4 atoms. The modes of metal–ligand connectivity at Zn3 and Zn4 are quite similar, and for them both contain slightly distorted tetrahedral Zn­(II) centers that link to three oxygen atoms from symmetry equivalents of all three syn–syn bidentate carboxylate groups. The differences lie on the fourth apical sites of Zn­(II) centers that are occupied by syn-coordinated carboxylate groups for Zn3 centers, and by nitrogen atoms from 4,4′-bpy ligands for Zn4 centers. Zn5 also adopts slightly distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry, completed by three oxygen atoms from three different cpop3– ligands, respectively, and one nitrogen atom of the bridging 4,4′-bpy ligand. Different from other Zn­(II) atoms, Zn6 is five-coordinated by three oxygen atoms from three different cpop3– ligands on the equatorial plane, and two water molecules at the axial position to form a slightly distorted trigonal bipyramid coordination geometry. The Zn5 and Zn6 atoms are bridged by two syn–syn bidentate carboxylate groups to form the second binuclear unit [Zn2(COO)2]. There are six independent cpop3– ligands and two 4,4′-bpy ligands extending from the tetra-nuclear unit. Each of the above-mentioned 4,4′-bpy ligand serves as a linker connecting an adjacent tetra-nuclear unit, and the above six cpop3– ligands can be divided into two types, which are entitled type A and type B. Type A of cpop3– ligand acts as a three connected node to link two paddle-wheel units and one tetra-nuclear unit (O1–O7/C1–C15; O15–O21/C31–C45) (). The cpop3– ligands around the paddle-wheel units can also be ascribed to this type. Type B of cpop3– ligands can be present as a bridge to connect two tetra-nuclear units (O8–O14/C16–C30; O22–O28/C46–C60) (). Consequently the tetra-nuclear unit can be abstracted to a 6-connected node to link two tetra-nuclear nodes and four 3-connected cpop3– ligand nodes (). In this way, the structure of 4 can be rationalized as a (3,6,6)-connected net. The molar ratio of the three types of nodes is 2:1:1. Thus, the whole framework of 4 is symbolized as an unusual (4.62)2(42.69.83.10)­(44.68.83) network (Figure b). Cocrystallization of complex 4 and its enantiomer ultimately gives a racemic mixture, which can be supported by no signal of the solid-state circular dichroism (CD) spectrum ().

There are six independent cpop3- ligands and two 4,4'-bpy ligands extending from the tetra-nuclear unit. Each of the above-mentioned 4,4'-bpy ligand serves as a linker connecting an adjacent tetra-nuclear unit, and the above six cpop3- ligands can be divided into two types, which are entitled type A and type B. Type A of cpop3- ligand acts as a three connected node to link two paddle-wheel units and one tetra-nuclear unit (O1-O7/C1-C15; O15-O21/C31-C45) (). The cpop3- ligands around the paddle-wheel units can also be ascribed to this type. Type B of cpop3- ligands can be present as a bridge to connect two tetra-nuclear units (O8-O14/C16-C30; O22-O28/C46-C60) (). Consequently the tetra-nuclear unit can be abstracted to a 6-connected node to link two tetra-nuclear nodes and four 3-connected cpop3- ligand nodes (). In this way, the structure of 4 can be rationalized as a (3,6,6)-connected net. The molar ratio of the three types of nodes is 2:1:1. Thus, the whole framework of 4 is symbolized as an unusual (4.62)2(42.69.83.10)(44.68.83) network (Figure b). Cocrystallization of complex 4 and its enantiomer ultimately gives a racemic mixture, which can be supported by no signal of the solid-state circular dichroism (CD) spectrum ().

elements.content: Complex 5 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅, and its structure features a 3D pillared-layer like framework. As shown in Figure , the asymmetric unit contains two Zn­(II) ions, a cpop3– ligand, a half bpdb ligand, and a coordinated water molecule, in which Zn2 is on the inversion center with the occupancy of 0.5. The Zn1 adopts distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry, completed by four carboxylic oxygen atoms from four different cpop3– ligands. Quite differently, Zn2 ion is six-coordinated by four oxygen atoms in which half of the oxygen atoms are from two cpop3– ligands and the other two oxygen atoms are from aqua ligands on the equatorial plane and two nitrogen atoms of bpdb ligand at the axial positions resulting in the octahedral coordination geometry. Each phthalic group of the cpop3– ligand in 5 connects three tetrahedral Zn­(II) centers and one octahedral Zn­(II) center via syn–anti carboxylate bridge mode to form the infinite 2D layer (Figure a,b). Interestingly, the tetrahedral and octahedral Zn­(II) centers are arranged in rows, respectively, and these two types of rows stack alternately manifesting a two-dimensionally laminar feature in the b × c plane. The 3D framework of 5 is generated from the connection of the 2D layers pillared by cpop3– ligands and bpdb ligands coursing along the c axis (Figure d). All of the cpop3– ligands in 5 act as 5-connected linkers bridging five Zn­(II) centers via μ5-κO:κO′:κO″:κO′′′:κO′′′′ mode (Scheme f), and the bpdb ligands serve as μ2-bridges to bind two Zn2 centers of the adjacent layers.

elements.content:
Single-crystal X-ray diffraction study indicates that complex 6 crystallizes in the triclinic P1 space group. In addition, calculation by PLATON also supports the P1 space group for 6.

As shown in Figure a, the asymmetric unit of complex 6 consists of six crystallographically independent Zn­(II) ions, four cpop3– ligands, two types of azpy ligands, and four aqua ligands. The Zn1 ion adopts the distorted tetragonal pyramidal coordination geometry, completed by four carboxylic oxygen atoms from four different cpop3– ligands. Differently, the Zn2 ion possesses a slightly distorted octahedral coordination geometry with two oxygen atoms from two cpop3– ligands, two nitrogen atoms from two azpy ligands, and two terminally coordinated water molecules. The last four zinc centers are five-coordinated and located in different coordination environments. Zn3, Zn4, Zn5 are surrounded by a tetragonal pyramid of O5, while the Zn6 is in a trigonal bipyramid of NO4. The distorted tetragonal pyramidal coordination geometries of Zn3–Zn5 are all constructed from one chelating carboxylic group of the cpop3– ligand and three oxygen atoms from the other three different cpop3– ligands. The bipyramidal coordination environment of Zn6 center is completed by one carboxylic oxygen atom (O24E), one nitrogen atom of the pyridyl ligand and one water molecule (O31) at the trigonal base, and another carboxylic oxygen atom (O27A) and water molecule (O32) at the axial sites. The oxygen atoms (O12, O19, O27) in chelating carboxyl groups interact fairly weakly with the Zn centers, which leads to longer Zn–O distances of 2.4886(4) Å (Zn3–O27D), 2.4244(4) Å (Zn4–O12E), and 2.3848(4) Å (Zn5–O19F) than those expected for Zn­(II) coordination bonds (Table ). The coordination environments around the four cpop3– ligands are also different from each other, which are depicted in Scheme f–i. The two types of azpy ligands have different coordination modes. One azpy ligand terminally coordinates to the Zn2 ion, and the other azpy ligand acts as a bridge to connect the Zn2 and Zn6 centers.

elements.content: As seen in Figure d, complex 6 features a quadruple layer structure constructed from two types of bilayers (bilayers A and B) linked by Zn2 ions and bridging azpy ligands. In bilayer A, two cpop3– ligands coordinate to Zn1 and Zn4 ions through 4- and 4′-carboxylic groups to form elliptical rings, and these rings stack along the crystallographic a axis through the coordination of 3-carboxylic groups and Zn1 and Zn4 centers to manifest a 1D chain (Figure b). The adjacent chains extend their structures to a bilayer structure through sharing the joints of Zn1 and Zn4 centers. The bilayer B is quite similar to the above bilayer, except that the points of junction consist of Zn3, Zn5, and Zn6 centers instead of Zn1 and Zn4 centers (Figure c). As shown in Figure d, the azpy ligands are located in the channels formed by neighboring elliptical rings along the crystallographic a axis. The bilayer A links the Zn2 centers through the 3-carboxylic groups (O4–C8–O3), and the bilayer B connects the Zn2 centers via both the 3′-carboxylic groups (O15–C37–O16) and the bridging azpy ligands. In this way, a novel quadruple layer structure of 6 containing double bilayer moieties is built up. To the best of our knowledge, this double bilayer like the quadruple layer structure is still relatively undeveloped. The adjoining 2D layers further stack via the strong O–H···O interactions between water molecules and carboxyl groups (O31···O12i  = 2.648(8) Å, O31···O9ii = 3.048(8) Å) and O–H···N interaction between water molecules and uncoordinated pyridyl groups (O32···N2iii = 2.809(9) Å,), giving a 3D supramolecular framework (Figure e). Complex 6 and its enantiomer crystallize together and compose a racemic mixture, which can be supported by no signal of the solid-state circular dichroism (CD) spectrum ().

elements.content: In this Article, complexes 1–6 were prepared as single-phase crystalline products by hydrothermal reactions of semirigid V-shaped tricarboxylate ligand H3cpop and Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O together with or without corresponding N-donor assistant ligands. The experiments and structural research remind us to study the effects of reaction conditions on the final structures. When the pH value of a mixture containing H3cpop, Zn­(II) salt, 4,4′-bpy, and water was adjusted to an acidic condition (pH = 3), a low-dimensional structure of complex 3 was obtained. The H3cpop ligand in 3 is partly deprotonated to Hcpop2– ligand with one protonated carboxyl group remaining as hydrogen-bond donor, which plays an important role in constructing supramolecular architecture. Yet when the pH value of the above mixture of reactants was adjusted to the alkaline (pH = 8) under similar reaction condition, the rod-shaped crystals of 4 were isolated. In the structure of complex 4, all carboxyl groups of H3cpop ligands are fully deprotonated, leading to a 3D framework.
elements.clean_text:
The Effects of pH Value

In this Article, complexes 1-6 were prepared as single-phase crystalline products by hydrothermal reactions of semirigid V-shaped tricarboxylate ligand H3cpop and Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O together with or without corresponding N-donor assistant ligands. The experiments and structural research remind us to study the effects of reaction conditions on the final structures. When the pH value of a mixture containing H3cpop, Zn(II) salt, 4,4'-bpy, and water was adjusted to an acidic condition (pH = 3), a low-dimensional structure of complex 3 was obtained. The H3cpop ligand in 3 is partly deprotonated to Hcpop2- ligand with one protonated carboxyl group remaining as hydrogen-bond donor, which plays an important role in constructing supramolecular architecture. Yet when the pH value of the above mixture of reactants was adjusted to the alkaline (pH = 8) under similar reaction condition, the rod-shaped crystals of 4 were isolated. In the structure of complex 4, all carboxyl groups of H3cpop ligands are fully deprotonated, leading to a 3D framework.

elements.content: To investigate the thermal stability of these complexes, the thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) experiments were carried out in the temperature range of 30–800 °C under a flow of nitrogen with a heating rate of 10 °C min–1 (Figure ). Complex 1 was stable up to about 100 °C, and then a weight loss of 13.00% was found between 100 and 260 °C, which is in agreement with the departure of three coordinated water molecules (calcd 12.88%). A total loss of 3.29% was observed for 2 in the temperature range of 50–165 °C, which can be attributed to the loss of lattice water molecules (calcd 3.19%), and the decomposition of the residue was observed at about 250 °C. For complex 3, the weight loss in the range of 30–160 °C corresponds to the departure of two lattice water molecules and one coordinated aqua molecules (calcd, 8.27%; found, 8.42%), and then the framework undergoes decomposition in the range of 160–500 °C. There is no obvious weight loss before 300 °C for complex 4, and the compound decomposes rapidly on further heating. As to 5, a weight loss of 3.57% was observed in the temperature range of 140–210 °C, which corresponds to the release of the coordinated water molecules (calcd 3.46%), and then the framework was found to decompose at about 350 °C. A total loss of 3.63% was observed for 6 in the temperature range of 120–170 °C, which can be attributed to the loss of four aqua ligands (calcd 3.55%), and the decomposition of the residue was observed at about 305 °C.

elements.content: As a series of d10 metal–organic hybrid coordination polymers, the solid-state emission spectra of complexes 1–6 together with the ligand H3cpop and the N-donor auxiliary ligands used in this work have been investigated at room temperature, and related data are listed in . The emission spectra of complexes 1–6, H3cpop, and the N-donor auxiliary ligands are shown in Figure . Excitation at 350 nm leads to an intense blue fluorescent emission band at 404 nm for 1, which can be assigned to intraligand (π–π*) fluorescent emissions of the ligand Hcpop2–. Similar to 1, compound 2 also exhibits a supramolecular architecture based on the discrete units, but it is quite another structure. The phen coligand dramatically affects both assembled process and fluorescent property. The emission spectrum of complex 2 contains two peaks at 373 and 391 nm and a weak shoulder band at 413 nm (λex = 310 nm), respectively. These bands of 2 are consistent with the emission wavelength of the free ligands (H3cpop and phen) (Figure b, ). Although complexes 3 and 4 both contain similar 4,4′-bpy as auxiliary ligands, they display different luminescent behaviors. Irradiation of complex 4 at 350 nm results in a blue fluorescent emission band at 435 nm, which closely matches those of the fluorophore ligands H3cpop and 4,4′-bpy, indicating the metal-perturbed intraligand charge transfers. While complex 3 shows intense red luminescent emissions under UV/blue irradiation, its solid-state emission spectrum reveals two emission bands at 433 and 609 nm (λex = 360 nm). The former with a relatively weaker emission band is similar to the emission bands of 4, and the later stronger emission (609 nm) is significantly red-shifted as compared to those for the free ligands. The emission band of 609 nm in 3 can be assumably assigned to ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) of protonated 4,4′-bpy and Zn­(II) center. The solid-state emission spectrum of 5 at room temperature displays a weak emission band centered at 437 nm with excitation maximum at 350 nm. As compared to the bpdb ligand (λem = 470, 605 nm), a remarkable blue shift is observed. This emission band may be caused by LMCT of bpdb ligand or metal-perturbed intraligand charge transfers of H3cpop ligand. The spectrum of complex 6 shows a week emission band at 442 nm, which can probably be assigned to the intraligand (π–π*) fluorescent emission of both H3cpop and azpy. It is obvious that the configuration and the coordination mode of the auxiliary ligands can not only affect the structures, but also efficiently adjust the photoluminescence properties of the complexes. In addition, complexes 1–4 show intense luminescent emissions under UV/blue irradiation, which may be considered as promising candidates for the exploration of fluorescent materials (Figure ).

elements.content: In summary, six zinc­(II)-4-(4-carboxyphenoxy)­phthalate complexes with a variety of discrete one-, two-, and three-dimensional architectures have been synthesized with the help of a series of rationally selected N-donor ligands. A notable structural feature is that the pairs of complexes 3 and 4 were assembled by the same materials but bearing different structures. This phenomenon indicates that the reaction pH value plays an important role in the formation of the final structure. In addition, photoluminescence properties of the complexes were studied in the solid state at room temperature. The result reveals that the coordination modes of the multicarboxylate and the assistant N-donor ligands can not only affect the construction of coordination framework but also may further mediate their optical properties. It is believed that the initiatory research of this work will provide further access to the rational design and synthesis of the novel functional coordination polymers based on semirigid V-shaped tricarboxylate ligands.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, six zinc(II)-4-(4-carboxyphenoxy)phthalate complexes with a variety of discrete one-, two-, and three-dimensional architectures have been synthesized with the help of a series of rationally selected N-donor ligands. A notable structural feature is that the pairs of complexes 3 and 4 were assembled by the same materials but bearing different structures. This phenomenon indicates that the reaction pH value plays an important role in the formation of the final structure. In addition, photoluminescence properties of the complexes were studied in the solid state at room temperature. The result reveals that the coordination modes of the multicarboxylate and the assistant N-donor ligands can not only affect the construction of coordination framework but also may further mediate their optical properties. It is believed that the initiatory research of this work will provide further access to the rational design and synthesis of the novel functional coordination polymers based on semirigid V-shaped tricarboxylate ligands.

cln_elements.content:
A mixture of Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (0.4 mmol, 118 mg), H3cpop (0.1 mmol, 32 mg), and H2O (10 mL) was placed in a Teflon-lined steel autoclave (23 mL). The pH of this mixture solution was about 6.0. The autoclave was sealed, heated to 120 °C, and held at the temperature for 96 h. The autoclave was allowed to cool to 30 °C for 24 h. Colorless block-shaped crystals of compound 1 were collected in 68% yield based on H3cpop. Anal. Calcd for C15O10H14Zn (M r = 419.65): C, 42.93; H, 3.36. Found: C, 43.12; H, 3.28. Selected IR data (KBr pellet, cm–1): 3302 (s), 2502 (m), 1897 (w), 1676 (s), 1587 (vs), 1392 (vs), 1261 (vs), 1242 (vs), 1169 (s), 1148 (m), 988 (w), 834 (m), 777 (s), 675 (m), 630 (m), 575 (m).

Synthesis of [Zn­(Hcpop)­(phen)­(H<sub>2</sub>O)]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>2</bold>)

A mixture of Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (0.4 mmol, 118 mg), H3cpop (0.1 mmol, 32 mg), phen (0.1 mmol, 20 mg), and 10 mL of H2O was sealed in a Teflon-lined steel autoclave (23 mL), adjusting the pH to 8.0 by addition of 0.5 M NaOH solution, heated at 120 °C for 72 h, and then it was slowly cooled to room temperature. Colorless block-shaped crystals were obtained by filtration in 76% yield based on H3cpop. Anal. Calcd for C27N2O8H18Zn (M r = 563.83): C, 57.51; H, 3.22; N, 4.97. Found: C, 57.23; H, 3.25; N, 4.85. Selected IR data (KBr pellet, cm–1): 3416 (m), 3061 (m), 2625 (w), 2498 (w), 1713 (s), 1583 (vs), 1427 (s), 1398 (vs), 1257 (s), 1230 (vs), 1153 (m), 851 (m), 726 (m).

Synthesis of [Zn<sub>2</sub>(Hcpop)<sub>2</sub>(4,4′-bpy)<sub>3</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub>·4<italic toggle="yes">n</italic>H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>3</bold>)

A mixture of Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (0.4 mmol, 118 mg), H3cpop (0.1 mmol, 32 mg), byp (0.1 mmol, 16 mg), and H2O (10 mL) was placed in a Teflon-lined steel autoclave (23 mL), adjusting the pH to 3.0 by addition of 0.5 M HNO3 solution. The autoclave was sealed, heated to 140 °C, and held at the temperature for 72 h. The autoclave was allowed to cool to 30 °C for 24 h. The resulting yellow solution was kept sealing at ambient temperature in air for 72 h, and red lamellar crystals of 3 were filtered in 37% yield based on H3cpop. Anal. Calcd for C60N6O20H52Zn2 (M r = 1307.90): C, 55.10; H, 4.01; N, 6.42. Found: C, 55.35; H, 3.94; N, 6.49. Selected IR data (KBr pellet, cm–1): 3806 (m), 3073 (m), 2635 (w), 1703 (m), 1611 (vs), 1600 (vs), 1563 (vs), 1418 (s), 1387 (vs), 1259 (s), 1223 (s), 1158 (m), 1068 (w), 812 (m), 628 (m).

Synthesis of [Zn<sub>6</sub>(cpop)<sub>4</sub>(4,4′-bpy)<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>4</bold>)

The preparation of 4 was similar to that of 3 except that the pH value was adjusted to 8.0 by addition of 0.5 M NaOH solution. After being cooled to room temperature, colorless rod-shaped crystals of 4 were filtered in 70% yield based on H3cpop. Anal. Calcd for C80N4O30H44Zn6 (M r = 1933.52): C, 49.58; H, 2.50; N, 2.89. Found: C, 49.35; H, 2.54; N, 2.82. Synthesis of [Zn<sub>3</sub>(cpop)<sub>2</sub>(bpdb)­(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>5</bold>)

A mixture of Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (0.3 mmol, 89 mg), H3cpop (0.1 mmol, 32 mg), bpdb (0.1 mmol, 23 mg), and 10 mL of H2O was sealed in a Teflon-lined steel autoclave (23 mL), adjusting the pH to 8.0 by addition of 0.5 M NaOH solution, heated at 140 °C for 72 h, whereupon it was cooled slowly to 30 °C. Brown needle-shaped crystals of 5 were separated by filtration with the yield of 71% based on H3cpop. Anal. Calcd for C42N4O16H28Zn3 (M r = 1040.92): C, 48.46; H, 2.71; N, 5.38. A mixture of Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (1 mmol, 297 mg), H3cpop (0.1 mmol, 32 mg), dpda (0.15 mmol, 27 mg), and 10 mL of H2O was sealed in a Teflon-lined steel autoclave (23 mL), adjusting the pH to 8.0 by addition of 0.5 M NaOH solution, heated at 160 °C for 72 h, and then red rodlike crystals of 6 were obtained after the reactor was cooled to room temperature with the yield of 81% based on H3cpop. cln_elements.content: To investigate the thermal stability of these complexes, the thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) experiments were carried out in the temperature range of 30–800 °C under a flow of nitrogen with a heating rate of 10 °C min–1 (Figure ). Complex 1 was stable up to about 100 °C, and then a weight loss of 13.00% was found between 100 and 260 °C, which is in agreement with the departure of three coordinated water molecules (calcd 12.88%). A total loss of 3.29% was observed for 2 in the temperature range of 50–165 °C, which can be attributed to the loss of lattice water molecules (calcd 3.19%), and the decomposition of the residue was observed at about 250 °C. For complex 3, the weight loss in the range of 30–160 °C corresponds to the departure of two lattice water molecules and one coordinated aqua molecules (calcd, 8.27%; found, 8.42%), and then the framework undergoes decomposition in the range of 160–500 °C. There is no obvious weight loss before 300 °C for complex 4, and the compound decomposes rapidly on further heating. As to 5, a weight loss of 3.57% was observed in the temperature range of 140–210 °C, which corresponds to the release of the coordinated water molecules (calcd 3.46%), and then the framework was found to decompose at about 350 °C. A total loss of 3.63% was observed for 6 in the temperature range of 120–170 °C, which can be attributed to the loss of four aqua ligands (calcd 3.55%), and the decomposition of the residue was observed at about 305 °C.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Thermal Analyses

To investigate the thermal stability of these complexes, the thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) experiments were carried out in the temperature range of 30-800 °C under a flow of nitrogen with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1 (Figure ). Complex 1 was stable up to about 100 °C, and then a weight loss of 13.00% was found between 100 and 260 °C, which is in agreement with the departure of three coordinated water molecules (calcd 12.88%). A total loss of 3.29% was observed for 2 in the temperature range of 50-165 °C, which can be attributed to the loss of lattice water molecules (calcd 3.19%), and the decomposition of the residue was observed at about 250 °C. For complex 3, the weight loss in the range of 30-160 °C corresponds to the departure of two lattice water molecules and one coordinated aqua molecules (calcd, 8.27%; found, 8.42%), and then the framework undergoes decomposition in the range of 160-500 °C. There is no obvious weight loss before 300 °C for complex 4, and the compound decomposes rapidly on further heating. As to 5, a weight loss of 3.57% was observed in the temperature range of 140-210 °C, which corresponds to the release of the coordinated water molecules (calcd 3.46%), and then the framework was found to decompose at about 350 °C. A total loss of 3.63% was observed for 6 in the temperature range of 120-170 °C, which can be attributed to the loss of four aqua ligands (calcd 3.55%), and the decomposition of the residue was observed at about 305 °C.
